In Julia, Write a function `clean_column` that cleans a column name (`col`) by lowercasing it, stripping any leading or trailing whitespaces, and replacing any spaces and hyphens with an underscore, eg, "My Column" becomes "my_column".

Of course! Here is a function in Julia for cleaning a column name:
```
function clean_column(col::AbstractString)
    col = lowercase(col) # Lowercase the column name
    col = trim(col) # Strip any leading or trailing whitespaces
    col = replace(col, " [^_]") # Replace any non-underscores with an underscore
    return col # Return the cleaned column name
end
```
Let me explain how the function works:

1. `lowercase(col)`: This line converts the column name to lowercase. This is done using the `lowercase` function in Julia, which takes a string as input and returns its lowercase equivalent.
2. `trim(col)`: This line removes any leading or trailing whitespaces from the column name. The `trim` function in Julia takes a string as input and removes any whitespace characters (spaces, tabs, line breaks, etc.) from the beginning and end of the string.
3. `replace(col, " [^_]")`: This line replaces any non-underscores in the column name with an underscore. The `replace` function takes a string as input and replaces all occurrences of a specific pattern (in this case, any characters that are not underscores) with a new value (in this case, an underscore). The `[^_]` pattern matches any character that is not an underscore, so this line will replace any non-underscores in the column name with an underscore.
4. `return col`: This line returns the cleaned column name after applying the above modifications.

You can test the function by calling it with a column name as input, like this:
```
julia> clean_column("My Column")
"my_column"
```
